question:
Which of the following varieties of rice is known as the miracle rice for India and was first harvested in 1967 with exceptional yield?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The rice variety IR8 is famously known as the “Miracle Rice” of India.
  • It was developed by the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) in the Philippines.
  • IR8 was introduced and first harvested in India in 1967, showing exceptionally high yields compared to traditional varieties.
  • It played a vital role during the Green Revolution in improving rice production and combating food shortages.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) IR9 – Also a HYV variety but introduced after IR8.
  • (c) PETA – A local rice variety, not linked to Green Revolution miracle status.
  • (d) DGWG – Dwarf Gene Wheat Germplasm; relates to wheat, not rice.

Answer: (b) IR8

question:
For Kharif crops, the temperature required for farming is above 25 degrees Celsius with high humidity and annual rainfall above ________ cm.

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Kharif crops are sown at the beginning of the monsoon season (June–July) and harvested by September–October.
  • These crops require:
    • High temperature – generally above 25°C
    • High humidity
    • Annual rainfall of more than 100 cm
  • These conditions support crops like rice, maize, cotton, and jowar that thrive in wet and warm climates.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) 16 cm, (b) 50 cm, (d) 35 cm – These rainfall levels are too low to support water-intensive crops like rice.

Answer: (c) 100

question:
The agricultural land below the main canal water level forms the ________.

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The agricultural land located below the main canal water level is known as the command area.
  • This is the area that can be irrigated using gravity flow, without the need for pumps or lifts.
  • It forms a natural catchment where water flows directly from the canal to the fields.
  • The command area is divided into:
    • Gross Command Area (GCA) – total area under the command of a canal
    • Culturable Command Area (CCA) – area suitable for cultivation

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Lift system – Involves pumping water to higher elevation lands.
  • (c) Flow system – A general term, but not specific to land classification.
  • (d) Warabandi – It is a rotational water distribution system, not a land area term.

Answer: (a) command area

question:
_______ land is suitable for regular cropping.

SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Arable land refers to land that is suitable for ploughing and growing crops regularly.
  • It is fertile, well-irrigated, and can sustain continuous cultivation.
  • Such land supports seasonal and commercial crops and forms the backbone of agriculture-based economies.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Barren – Land that is infertile and unproductive, unsuitable for agriculture.
  • (c) Marginal – Land with low productivity, often used under pressure but not ideal for regular cropping.
  • (d) Urban – Refers to city or town land, not used for agriculture.

Answer: (a) Arable

question:
Which group of crops belong to fibre crops and are produced on a large scale in India ?

SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Fibre crops are grown primarily for their fibres, which are used in making cloth, ropes, mats, etc.
  • In India, the two most important fibre crops grown on a large scale are:
    • Jute – majorly grown in West Bengal, Assam, and Bihar
    • Hemp – cultivated in some parts for industrial fibres
  • These crops contribute significantly to India’s textile and packaging industries.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Gram and tur – These are pulses, not fibre crops.
  • (c) Tea and coffee – These are beverage crops.
  • (d) Wheat and rice – These are cereal food crops, not fibre crops.

Answer: (b) Jute and hemp

question:
Which of the following crops is the only genetically modified (GM) crop approved for commercial cultivation in India?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Bt Cotton is the only genetically modified (GM) crop that has been officially approved for commercial cultivation in India.
  • It was introduced in 2002 and contains a gene from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) that helps the plant produce a toxin to resist bollworm pests.
  • Bt cotton has significantly increased cotton yield and reduced pesticide use in India.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Bt Brinjal – Approved in Bangladesh, but not cleared for commercial cultivation in India due to safety concerns.
  • (b) Mustard – Genetically modified mustard (DMH-11) is still under review and not yet approved for commercial use.
  • (d) Tomato – No GM tomato is approved for cultivation in India.

Answer: (c) Bt Cotton

question:
Cultivating large farms with moderately low inputs of labour and capital is referred to as ________.

SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Extensive cultivation refers to farming practiced on large plots of land with low labour and capital input per unit area.
  • This method depends more on the natural fertility of soil and climatic conditions than on fertilizers, irrigation, or mechanisation.
  • It is common in regions with low population density, such as parts of USA, Canada, and Australia.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Hybrid cultivation – Involves growing high-yield or genetically improved crops using hybrid seeds.
  • (c) Intensive cultivation – Involves high input of labour, capital, and resources on small land to increase productivity.
  • (d) Capitalist cultivation – Refers to farming as a business enterprise, involving investment and profit motives.

Answer: (b) extensive cultivation

question:
Which of the following crops is classified as fine grain?

SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Wheat is classified as a fine grain cereal, meaning it has smaller, finer grains and is often used to make flour for bread, chapati, and other food items.
  • Fine grains are typically nutrient-rich, easy to digest, and cultivated widely in temperate and subtropical regions.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Bajra (Pearl Millet) – Coarse grain
  • (b) Ragi (Finger Millet) – Coarse grain
  • (c) Maize (Corn) – Also considered a coarse grain in Indian classification
  • These are coarse cereals, rich in fiber and mainly grown in arid regions.

Answer: (d) Wheat

question:
Which of the following is the most suitable application of rainwater harvesting?

SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (2nd shift)
option_4: Use for industrial purposes
solution:
• The most suitable application of rainwater harvesting is irrigation, especially in areas with irregular rainfall or water scarcity.
  • Collected rainwater can be stored in tanks or underground reservoirs and later used to water agricultural fields, gardens, and crops.
  • This reduces dependency on groundwater and ensures sustainable farming practices.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Cooking – Rainwater is not usually safe for direct consumption without purification.
  • (c) Water for pets – Same safety issue; not a primary or large-scale use.
  • (d) Industrial purposes – Possible, but not the most common or efficient use compared to irrigation.

Answer: (b) Irrigation

question:
What is meant by subsistence agriculture ?

SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (3rd shift)
option_1: Agricultural output is sufficient for the country.
option_2: Agriculturists produce primarily for themselves.
option_3: Agriculture generates sufficient income.
option_4: Agriculturists produce primarily for the market.
solution:
• Subsistence agriculture refers to a type of farming where farmers grow crops mainly for their own consumption, not for sale or profit.
  • The output is usually just enough to meet the needs of the farmer's family.
  • It involves traditional methods, low yield, and minimal use of technology or market dependency.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Implies national sufficiency, which is unrelated to subsistence-level farming.
  • (c) Subsistence farming rarely generates significant income.
  • (d) Refers to commercial agriculture, not subsistence.

Answer: (b) Agriculturists produce primarily for themselves

question:
Which of the following states of India still uses the ancient bamboo drip irrigation method?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Meghalaya is one of the few states in India where the ancient bamboo drip irrigation system is still in use.
  • This method involves channeling water from streams using bamboo pipes, distributing it drop by drop to fields, especially on hilly terrains.
  • It is highly efficient, minimizes water loss, and is eco-friendly, relying entirely on gravity and indigenous techniques.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Telangana, (c) Maharashtra, and (d) Chhattisgarh use more modern irrigation systems like canal, drip (plastic-based), or tube wells rather than traditional bamboo systems.

Answer: (b) Meghalaya

question:
Which of the following classification bases of industry applies to the products- cotton, jute, wool, silk, textile, rubber, tea, sugar, coffee, edible oil ?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The correct classification for products like cotton, jute, wool, silk, textile, rubber, tea, sugar, coffee, and edible oil is Agro-based industries.
  • These industries derive raw materials directly from agriculture or animal husbandry, such as plants, crops, or livestock.
  • They process farm products into consumable or usable goods.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Key industries – Refer to basic and heavy industries like iron, steel, and energy.
  • (b) Consumer industries – Refer to industries producing finished goods for direct consumption, but may not all be agro-based.
  • (d) Mineral based industries – Use minerals like iron, coal, or limestone as raw materials, not agricultural products.

Answer: (c) Agro based industries

question:
6% of the total workforce is engaged in _________ and allied sector activities (Census of India 2011).

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• As per the Census of India 2011, around 6% of the total workforce in India was engaged in agriculture and allied sector activities.
  • These include crop cultivation, livestock rearing, forestry, fishing, etc.
  • This highlights the predominant role of agriculture in providing employment in India, especially in rural areas.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Hunting and gathering – Extremely minimal and not significant in modern workforce data.
  • (b) Manufacturing – Involves industrial work, but employs a much smaller percentage compared to agriculture.
  • (d) Mining – Limited to certain regions and contributes far less to overall employment.

Answer: (c) Agriculture

question:
Cultivation of rice needs high rainfall ________.

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Afternoon)
option_1: Low temperature and low humidity
option_2: High temperature and low humidity
option_3: High temperature and high humidity
option_4: Low temperature and high humidity
solution:
• Rice cultivation requires high rainfall, high temperature (around 25–35°C), and high humidity.
  • These climatic conditions are ideal because:
    • Rice is a water-intensive crop, needing standing water during its early growth stages.
    • High humidity aids in proper growth and grain development.
    • Warm temperatures support fast vegetative and reproductive growth.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) & (d): Low temperature hampers rice growth.
  • (b): Low humidity is not suitable for paddy as it increases water evaporation.

Answer: (c) High temperature and high humidity

question:
The cultivation of ________ was introduced on the Baba Budan Hills in India.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The cultivation of coffee was first introduced in India on the Baba Budan Hills in Chikmagalur district of Karnataka.
  • It is believed that Baba Budan, a 17th-century Sufi saint, brought seven coffee beans from Yemen and planted them in these hills, starting India's coffee journey.
  • Today, the region is a major hub for Arabica coffee cultivation in India.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Silk – Involves sericulture, not linked to Baba Budan Hills.
  • (b) Tea – Introduced in Assam and Darjeeling.
  • (d) Cardamom – Commonly grown in Kerala and parts of Tamil Nadu, not historically associated with Baba Budan Hills.

Answer: (c) Coffee

question:
Dr D.S. Athwal was known as the 'Father of___________Revolution in India'.

SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Dr. D.S. Athwal is popularly known as the 'Father of Wheat Revolution' in India.
  • He played a significant role in introducing high-yielding varieties (HYVs) of wheat, especially during the Green Revolution.
  • His collaboration with Norman Borlaug was instrumental in increasing wheat productivity and ensuring food security in India.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Oilseed – Associated with the Yellow Revolution.
  • (b) Rice – Linked more with scientists like Dr. Gurdev Khush.
  • (c) Millet – Not specifically associated with Dr. Athwal.

Answer: (d) Wheat

question:
"Agricultural Census" is conducted in India at an interval of _____.

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• In India, the Agricultural Census is conducted every five years.
  • It is organized by the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare.
  • The census collects data related to operational holdings, land use, tenancy, cropping patterns, etc., providing a comprehensive database for planning and policy formulation.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Six years, (c) Four years, (d) Ten years – These intervals are not officially designated for agricultural census in India.

Answer: (b) Five years

question:
Which of the following is termed as "sericulture" ?

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Afternoon)
option_4: Commercial rearing of silk worms
solution:
• Sericulture refers to the commercial rearing of silkworms for the production of silk.
  • It involves the cultivation of mulberry trees (to feed silkworms), breeding of Bombyx mori (domesticated silkworm), and harvesting of silk cocoons.
  • It is a labour-intensive and agro-based industry, especially practiced in states like Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, West Bengal, and Tamil Nadu.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Cultivation of grapes – Known as viticulture.
  • (b) Growing of fruits – Known as horticulture.
  • (c) Breeding of fish – Known as pisiculture.

Answer: (d) Commercial rearing of silk worms

question:
There are regions where farmers specialize in vegetables only. This type of farming is known as ______.

SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Truck farming refers to a type of specialized farming where farmers grow vegetables (and sometimes fruits) for sale in nearby markets.
  • The term “truck” originates from the old French word troquer, meaning to barter or exchange, not the vehicle.
  • It is market-oriented farming, common in urban fringes, where produce is quickly transported to cities.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Mixed farming – Involves both crop cultivation and livestock.
  • (b) Pastoral farming – Focuses on livestock rearing, not vegetables.
  • (c) Dairy farming – Involves milk production, not vegetable farming.

Answer: (d) Truck farming

question:
Which among the following terms means growing of fruits?

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Pomiculture refers to the cultivation of fruits, especially pome fruits like apples and pears.
  • It is a branch of horticulture that focuses on fruit-growing practices, including propagation, harvesting, and management.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Apiculture – The rearing of honeybees for honey and wax.
  • (b) Arboriculture – The study and cultivation of trees and shrubs, mainly for ornamental or shade purposes.
  • (d) Sericulture – The commercial rearing of silkworms for silk production.

Answer: (c) Pomiculture

question:
It is a tropical as well as a subtropical crop. It grows well in hot and humid climates with a temperature of 21°C to 27°C and an annual rainfall between 75cm and 100cm. Which of the crops is being talked about in the information given above?

SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The crop described grows in tropical and subtropical regions, prefers hot and humid climates, with temperature between 21°C to 27°C and rainfall between 75 cm to 100 cm.
  • These climatic conditions are ideal for sugarcane cultivation.
  • Sugarcane also requires a long growing season and abundant water for good yield.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Cotton – Grows in drier conditions; needs high temperature but less humidity.
  • (c) Maize – Requires moderate temperature and less rainfall than sugarcane.
  • (d) Rubber – Needs heavy rainfall (above 200 cm) and more humidity than specified.

Answer: (a) Sugarcane

question:
Cotton requires ____ temperature, light rainfall or irrigation,_____ frost- free days and bright sun-shine for its growth.

SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Cotton is a tropical crop that thrives in high temperatures.
  • It requires light rainfall or irrigation and about 210 frost-free days to mature.
  • Cotton also needs bright sunshine for healthy boll development.
  • The correct combination of high temperature and 210 frost-free days is essential for optimum growth.

Answer: (a) high, 210

question:
In India initially HYVP was implemented in about how much area?

SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• HYVP stands for High Yielding Varieties Programme, launched in 1966 as part of the Green Revolution.
  • It focused on introducing high-yielding varieties of wheat and rice, especially in areas with proper irrigation.
  • Initially, the program was implemented in 2 million hectares of land across selected regions in India.

Answer: (d) 2 million hectares

question:
In rainforests which kind of cultivation is practiced?

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• In rainforests, especially in tropical regions, Slash and Burn agriculture is commonly practiced.
  • It involves cutting down vegetation, letting it dry, and then burning it to clear land and add nutrients to the soil.
  • This is a form of shifting cultivation, mostly used by tribal and subsistence farmers in forested areas.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Dry farming – Suited for arid/dry regions, not rainforests.
  • (b) Vertical farming – Modern method using stacked layers, not used in forests.
  • (c) Terrace farming – Used in hilly areas, not dense forests.

Answer: (d) Slash and burn

question:
The Purple revolution was launched by the Union Ministry of Science & Technology in Jammu and Kashmir. This revolution is related to cultivation of which crop?

SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Purple Revolution was initiated by the Union Ministry of Science & Technology under the Aroma Mission.
  • It aims to promote the cultivation of lavender in Jammu and Kashmir, especially in the Doda and Udhampur regions.
  • Lavender farming helps increase farmers’ income, promotes agro-based startups, and reduces reliance on traditional crops.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Marigold, (b) Kashmiri Rose, and (d) Himalayan Indigo are not associated with the Purple Revolution.

Answer: (c) Lavender

question:
The Planning commission of India has divided India into how many Agro-climatic Zones?

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Planning Commission of India divided the country into 15 Agro-Climatic Zones.
  • This classification was based on climate, soil type, topography, farming practices, and availability of water resources.
  • The goal was to enable region-specific agricultural planning and improve productivity through tailored strategies.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) 25, (c) 18, (d) 20 are incorrect; they may relate to other schemes or classifications by different agencies (e.g., ICAR uses 127 agro-ecological zones).

Answer: (a) 15

question:
Which crop does not require high rainfall and high temperature?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Maize grows well in moderate rainfall (50–100 cm) and moderate temperature (around 21–27°C).
  • It does not require high rainfall and high temperature, making it suitable for drier regions compared to rice or jute.
  • In contrast:
    • Rice needs >100 cm rainfall and high humidity.
    • Jute needs >150 cm rainfall and hot weather.
    • Cotton needs high temperature and moderate rainfall.

Answer: (c) Maize

question:
Soilless agriculture is called ____.

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Soilless agriculture is known as Hydroponics.
  • It is a method of growing plants using nutrient-rich water instead of soil.
  • Roots are either supported by an inert medium (like coco peat or rock wool) or directly suspended in water.
  • It is widely used in urban farming, greenhouses, and space research due to space and soil constraints.

Answer: (a) hydroponics

question:
The word agriculture is derived from the Latin words ager and culture. What does ‘ager’ mean?

SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The word "Agriculture" comes from two Latin words:
    • "Ager" meaning soil or field,
    • and "Culture" meaning cultivation.
  • Thus, agriculture literally means cultivation of soil or land.

Answer: (b) Soil

question:
What is the percentage of land used for agriculture in India as per the 2009 data by National Institute of Hydrology?

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• According to 2009 data by the National Institute of Hydrology,

    approximately 09% of India’s total land area was used for agricultural purposes.

  • This includes land used for both food crops and cash crops.
  • India has one of the largest areas under cultivation in the world.

Answer: (a) 51.09%

question:
DDT adversely affects our environment because:

SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Evening)
option_1: it can kill beneficial insects like honey bees
option_2: it can allow growth of harmful insects
option_3: it can promote growth of harmful insects
option_4: it can kill harmful insects
solution:
• DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is a synthetic pesticide that was widely used in agriculture for controlling pests.
  • It is non-biodegradable and persists in the environment, leading to bioaccumulation in animals and humans.
  • It kills beneficial insects such as honey bees, which play a crucial role in pollination.
  • The loss of pollinators affects crop yields and disrupts the ecosystem balance.

Additional Information:

  • DDT is banned or restricted in many countries, including India, due to its harmful environmental impact.
  • It can enter the food chain and accumulate in fatty tissues of organisms, leading to biomagnification.
  • It caused eggshell thinning in birds like eagles and falcons, contributing to their population decline.

question:
India lost a large proportion of _________ growing area to Pakistan during partition.

SSC CGL 18/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• During the partition of India in 1947, a significant portion of cotton-growing areas went to Pakistan, especially those located in the Punjab region.
  • As a result, India faced a shortage of raw cotton, which was crucial for its textile industry.
  • This necessitated the import of cotton and also spurred the development of cotton cultivation in central and southern India.

Additional Information:

  • The western Punjab region, which became part of Pakistan, had fertile land suited for cotton farming.
  • To compensate for the loss, regions like Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Madhya Pradesh were promoted for cotton cultivation post-independence.
  • The textile mills of India, particularly in Mumbai and Ahmedabad, faced a major raw material crisis initially.

question:
Which of the following is the main food crop of the semi-arid areas of central and southern India?

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The main food crop of the semi-arid regions of central and southern India is Jowar (Sorghum).
  • Jowar is drought-resistant and can grow in low rainfall regions with poor soil fertility.
  • It is a staple food in Maharashtra, Karnataka, Telangana, and Madhya Pradesh.

Additional Information:

  • Jowar is rich in iron, fibre, and protein, making it a nutritious cereal.
  • It is classified as a millet and promoted under the Millet Mission in India.
  • India is the largest producer of Jowar in the world.

question:
Which of the following is a well-known variety of coffee initially brought to India from Yemen?

SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The Arabica variety of coffee is a well-known species that was initially brought to India from Yemen in the 17th century.
  • It is considered to be of high quality with mild flavor and lower caffeine content compared to other varieties.
  • Arabica is grown in the shade-grown plantations of Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.

Additional Information:

  • Baba Budan, a Sufi saint, is credited with bringing seven coffee beans from Yemen and planting them in the Baba Budan Hills of Karnataka.
  • Arabica accounts for about 60–70% of India's coffee production.
  • It is more susceptible to pests and diseases compared to Robusta (Canephora), but preferred for export due to its flavor.

question:
Which of the following is a variety of oilseed?

SSC CHSL 16/04/2021(Evening)
solution:
• Taramira is a variety of oilseed, primarily cultivated in arid and semi-arid regions of India.
  • It belongs to the mustard family (Brassicaceae) and is known for its resistance to drought.
  • The oil extracted from its seeds is used in cooking, pickling, and sometimes for medicinal purposes.

Additional Information:

  • Taramira is particularly suited for Rajasthan and dry areas where other oilseeds may not thrive.
  • The other options — Arabica, Robusta, and Liberica — are varieties of coffee, not oilseeds.

question:
The _________ water utilization is very high in the states of Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Tamil Nadu.

SSC CPO 24/11/2020(Evening)
solution:
• The ground water utilization is very high in the states of Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Tamil Nadu.
  • These states rely heavily on tube wells and bore wells for irrigation, particularly for crops like wheat, rice, and sugarcane.
  • Overuse of groundwater in these areas has led to serious depletion of aquifers and declining water tables.

Additional Information:

  • According to Central Ground Water Board (CGWB) data, Punjab and Haryana are among the most water-stressed regions in India.
  • Excessive use of groundwater for agriculture without adequate recharge is a key concern in these states.
  • Sustainable water practices like micro-irrigation and crop diversification are encouraged to reduce pressure on groundwater.

question:
A policy which involves fixing the maximum size of land which could be owned by an individual is called _______.

SSC CPO 25/11/2020(Evening)
solution:
• The correct term is Land ceiling.
  • It refers to a policy that limits the maximum amount of land an individual or household can legally own.
  • The objective is to redistribute surplus land to landless and marginal farmers to promote social justice and equity in land ownership.

Additional Information:

  • Land ceiling laws were introduced as part of land reform measures in post-independence India.
  • These laws helped prevent the emergence of large landholdings and encouraged agricultural equity.
  • Implementation varied across states, and loopholes were often used to bypass the limits.
